title: Amazon.com Rests Less Easily on Its Cloud
text:
Amazon.com, AMZN -0.15% the undisputed leader in the cloud, suddenly has a lot to prove.

Ahead of the tech giant’s third-quarter results Thursday, investors are watching one area in particular: Amazon’s AWS cloud-services unit has been a significant driver of growth and profits at the company over the past five years. But that record took a bit of a beating in the company’s previous report in late July, which showed a notable slowdown in revenue and earnings growth for the unit and a rare shortfall against Wall Street’s targets for the operation.

Amazon’s shares have fallen 11% since that report, setting the largest decline among big tech companies slated to post September-quarter results over the next few weeks. Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google, is up 9% in that time. It didn’t help Amazon that the Capital One Financial Corp. hack, in which a former AWS employee was accused of stealing more than 100 million records from the lender, was reported just days after its July results. Amazon is also now among the weakest big tech stocks for the year, with an 18% gain to date against the Nasdaq Composite’s 22% climb.

That has Wall Street smelling a bargain—especially since Amazon is one of the few S&P 500 stocks to have a unanimous “buy” rating from analysts. Indeed, at around 68 times forward earnings, Amazon’s shares look cheap against the multiple of 100 times forward earnings that the stock has averaged over the past four years, according to FactSet.

But that also speaks to Amazon’s unique challenge. The company has managed such a heady valuation precisely by giving investors the best of both worlds: a massive, scaled-up business still growing revenue at more than 20% annually while also expanding its bottom line. The cloud segment is a key component in the latter, especially as the company’s retail side now absorbs the costs for taking on more of its own deliveries—and delivering more of those products in a single day.

Analysts expect AWS revenue to log a rise of 37% for the third quarter to $9.1 billion. Operating income for AWS is projected at about $2.55 billion, which would produce a margin of 28%—up from the 25% reported in the previous quarter. Amazon still has a comfortable lead on cloud challengers including Microsoft and Google, and analysts widely expect overall cloud spending to remain resilient compared with other areas of corporate tech budgets that are getting pinched. But the company’s cloud can ill afford another slip.

Write to Dan Gallagher at dan.gallagher@wsj.com
description: An AWS target miss and the Capital One hack have punished the highflying stock since its latest report.
